snippet: The court ruled that people arrested for any offense, however minor, may be forced to strip before being jailed, even if there is no suspicion of contraband.
abstract: United States Supreme Court rules, 5-4, that officials may strip-search people arrested for any offense before admitting them to jails even if there is no reason to suspect the presence of contraband; procedures endorsed by the majority are forbidden by statute in at least 10 states and are at odds with the policies of federal authorities and international human rights treaties.
lead_paragraph: The court ruled that people arrested for any offense, however minor, may be forced to strip before being jailed, even if there is no suspicion of contraband.

headline.seo: Justices Approve Strip Searches for Any Offense
headline.main: Supreme Court Ruling Allows Strip Searches for Any Arrest
headline.print_headline: Justices Approve Strip-Search Use For Any Arrest
